channel.title: Strategic Management on Nadia Z. Humbert-Labeaumaz
channel.description: Recent content in Strategic Management on Nadia Z. Humbert-Labeaumaz

item.title: From Decision to Impact: The Strategic Role of Technical Judgement
item.description:
Introduction

In contemporary organizations, technology has become a strategic determinant of competitiveness, adaptability, and value creation. As such, every technical decision carries implications that extend beyond engineering performance into business continuity, scalability, and long-term sustainability.

item.title: Strategic Coherence: Managing Scope, Expectations, and Stakeholders
item.description:
Introduction

In complex organizational environments, the success of any project depends less on technical precision than on alignment between strategy and execution, expectations and capacity, and among diverse stakeholder interests. However, misalignment is rarely the result of poor planning alone; it often arises from fragmented communication, conflicting incentives, or a lack of shared understanding.

item.title: Dynamic Capabilities: Building Organizational Agility and Strategic Renewal
item.description:
Context

In fast-changing environments, traditional sources of competitive advantage, such as proprietary technology or market share, erode quickly. To remain resilient and relevant, organizations must cultivate what we call Dynamic Capabilities: the capacity to integrate, build, and reconfigure internal and external resources to address shifting opportunities and threats.

item.title: Porter's Five Forces: Assessing Competitive Structure and Market Attractiveness
item.description:
Context

Strategic planning requires insight into the competitive dynamics that define its external reality. Michael Porter’s Five Forces Framework, remains one of the most rigorous models for assessing industry structure, competitive pressure, and long-term profitability potential.

item.title: SWOT Analysis: From Diagnostic Framework to Strategic Synthesis
item.description:
Context

The SWOT Analysis remains one of the most enduring and widely used frameworks to understand where the organization stands, both in relation to itself and to its environment. Originally designed as a diagnostic tool, SWOT (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats) enables organizations to integrate internal capabilities with external conditions, creating a clear picture of strategic fit. However, the true value of the model lies in transforming these factors into strategic imperatives.

item.title: VRIO Framework: Assessing Internal Resources for Sustainable Advantage
item.description:
Context

Understanding competitive advantage requires looking to the resources and capabilities that allow an organization to perform better than its rivals. The VRIO Framework provides a structured method to evaluate which assets and competencies can create enduring strategic advantage rather than temporary success.

item.title: ESTEMPLE* Analysis: A Comprehensive Framework for Environmental Scanning
item.description:
Context

Every strategic plan begins with a simple question: In what environment does the organization operate, and how might that environment evolve? Traditional environmental analysis often relies on PESTEL (Political, Economic, Social, Technological, Environmental, and Legal factors). However, the complexity of today’s ecosystems requires a broader, more systemic perspective. The ESTEMPLE* model extends this logic by adding Media, Ethics, and other relevant factors, producing a richer lens through which to evaluate the macro-environmental forces shaping the organization’s trajectory.

item.title: What is a Social Entrepreneur?
item.description:
Today, social entrepreneurship is defined in many ways. This ambiguity can blur the identity of social entrepreneurs, undermine their credibility, weaken the relevance of the guidance they receive, and ultimately hinder their impact. That is why a shared definition is essential.

This article presents my perspective and insights on social entrepreneurs, based on primary research conducted with a small random sample in Toronto, Canada.

item.title: Winning on Simplicity: Aldi's Dual Strategy of Cost Leadership and Quality Differentiation
item.description:
Introduction

Over the years, Aldi blazed the trail for the hard-discounters within the US grocery retail industry. The firm’s current obsession with product quality, combined with its focus on low prices (Ramaswamy, 2020), suggests that winning for the company means offering the best quality at the lowest price.

item.title: Purpose Meets Profit: Insights from Emerging Social Entrepreneurs in Toronto
item.description:
Introduction

Social entrepreneurship has emerged as a distinctive response to complex social and environmental challenges that traditional business and public institutions have failed to address effectively. By combining entrepreneurial methods with social purpose, these ventures aim to create value that extends beyond financial profit. Yet, despite growing academic and policy interest, the lived experiences of social entrepreneurs, and the factors that shape their motivations, behaviours, and constraints, remain insufficiently understood.

item.title: From Retail to the Cloud: Strategic Reinvention and Competitive Advantage at Amazon
item.description:
Introduction

Amazon’s evolution from an online bookstore into a global technology ecosystem represents one of the most remarkable strategic transformations in modern business history. Founded in 1994 by Jeff Bezos, the company has expanded across e-commerce, logistics, entertainment, cloud computing, and artificial intelligence. Today, it dominates multiple industries simultaneously, driven by a culture of innovation, customer obsession, and data-centric decision-making.

item.title: Balancing Profit and Preservation: Sustainable Strategies for Wildlife Management in South Africa
item.description:
Introduction

Kruger National Park is one of the world’s largest and most biodiverse conservation areas, renowned for its ecological management practices and anti-poaching operations. It attracts millions of visitors each year, contributing significantly to South Africa’s tourism economy.
